Privacy-Preserving Data Deduplication for Enhancing Federated Learning of Language Models

Aydin Abadi1 1Equal contribution. Listing order is alphabetical. Newcastle University
aydin.abadi@ncl.ac.uk    Vishnu Asutosh Dasu1 Pennsylvania State University
vdasu@psu.edu    Sumanta Sarkar1 University of Warwick
sumanta.sarkar@warwick.ac.uk
Abstract

Deduplication is a vital preprocessing step that enhances machine learning model performance and saves training time and energy. However, enhancing federated learning through deduplication poses challenges, especially regarding scalability and potential privacy violations if deduplication involves sharing all clients' data. In this paper, we address the problem of deduplication in a federated setup by introducing a pioneering protocol, Efficient Privacy-Preserving Multi-Party Deduplication (EP-MPD). It efficiently removes duplicates from multiple clients' datasets without compromising data privacy. EP-MPD is constructed in a modular fashion, utilizing two novel variants of the Private Set Intersection protocol. Our extensive experiments demonstrate the significant benefits of deduplication in federated learning of large language models. For instance, we observe up to 19.61% improvement in perplexity and up to 27.95% reduction in running time. EP-MPD effectively balances privacy and performance in federated learning, making it a valuable solution for large-scale applications.

I Introduction

The application of machine learning (ML) has experienced rapid growth, becoming widely embraced by businesses due to its various benefits. As ML relies heavily on data, there is an inherent risk of privacy breaches associated with this process. Federated learning (FL) is one of the main steps towards privacy-preserving ML that allows training across multiple decentralized devices without exchanging data. In FL, devices compute local models based on their data and then share the local model updates with a central server. This server aggregates the updates to derive a global model that encapsulates the features of all the local data held by the individual devices [38].

The quality of the training data significantly influences the accuracy of an ML model. Data generated from real-world applications often lacks organization, leading to issues such as missing values, typos, format mismatches, outliers, or duplicated entries within the raw dataset. To ensure meaningful learning, the collected data must undergo a thorough data cleaning process [23]. Duplicated sequences are prevalent in text datasets. They can adversely affect the training process of Language Models (LMs). Lee et al. [31] investigated the Colossal Clean Crawled Corpus (C4) [44] dataset. They discovered a 61-word sequence within C4 that was repeated 61,036 times verbatim in the training dataset and 61 times in the validation set. As a result, the trained model generalized poorly on the dataset, and over 1%percent11\% of the unprompted model outputs were memorized and copied verbatim from the training dataset. Upon deduplicating the dataset, they reduced memorization by up to 10×10\times and, in certain cases, even improved perplexity by up to 10%percent1010\%.

Additionally, memorization negatively affects the privacy and fairness of LMs [12]. Memorization makes language models vulnerable to membership inference attacks [48, 37], data extraction attacks [39, 13], and can lead to copyright violations as LMs can regurgitate training data sequences from copyrighted sources [28]. Carlini et al. [12] conclude that bigger LMs memorize more and more duplicates increase memorization. Kandpal et al. [27] show that the success of most privacy attacks on LMs is largely due to the duplication in the training datasets. Furthermore, in the FL setting, malicious clients can exploit the memorization of LMs to extract sensitive information from honest clients' datasets [46]. Therefore, we must adopt data-cleaning practices to improve model utility and reduce the risks of privacy attacks.

While deduplication can improve model performance and reduce memorization, it also enhances training efficiency in various aspects [31]. Removing duplicates reduces GPU time and minimizes training costs in terms of time, money, and carbon footprint. This streamlined process optimizes resource utilization and contributes to more sustainable ML practices [7, 47, 42]. Sustainable development is a global priority, and aligning ML practices with this theme is crucial.

Based on the discussions thus far, it is evident that the deduplication of training data offers numerous benefits. Several real-world applications involve training with FL such as healthcare [3], smart city [25], and edge computing [51]. Some of these applications pose a risk of duplicates in the local training data across multiple devices. For example, Google Keyboard suggestions from a user's text query rely on FL [22]. Local models are trained in situ on Android phones with user data. In this setting, many text queries typed by the users across multiple phones are the same.

Therefore, for a FL process to be efficient and effective, participating devices must perform deduplication. When a data owner solely intends to remove duplicates from their dataset, the privacy risk is minimal since the data is entirely under the owner's control. In the context of FL, the scenario shifts significantly when deduplication is introduced. Multiple devices participating in FL may possess overlapping data, even after deduplicating their datasets. If they aim to deduplicate the combined dataset, one approach could involve sharing their raw data with each other and checking for intersections. However, this approach compromises privacy.

Hence, there is a necessity for privacy-preserving deduplication in FL, where participating devices would collaboratively deduplicate the combined datasets in a privacy-preserving fashion. This paper demonstrates how deduplication can be executed in FL without compromising the privacy of the data belonging to the individual devices.

I-A Overview of Privacy-Preserving Deduplication in FL

Consider nodes D1,…,Dnsubscript𝐷1…subscript𝐷𝑛D_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,D_{\scriptscriptstyle n} are involved in FL, where each Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{\scriptscriptstyle i} has a dataset Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. Effectively, the training in FL is conducted on the union of these datasets, i.e., ⋃i=1nSisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑆𝑖\bigcup\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle n}S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. If intersections exist among the datasets, FL will incorporate duplicates, leading to the drawbacks discussed earlier.

Consider nodes D1subscript𝐷1D_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and D2subscript𝐷2D_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}, each with datasets S1subscript𝑆1S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and S2subscript𝑆2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}, respectively implying that FL training occurs on S1∪S2subscript𝑆1subscript𝑆2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\cup S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}. If the intersection S1∩S2subscript𝑆1subscript𝑆2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\cap S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} is nonempty, training individually on S1subscript𝑆1S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and S2subscript𝑆2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} would mean training twice on the duplicate S1∩S2subscript𝑆1subscript𝑆2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\cap S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}. Thus, one of D1subscript𝐷1D_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and D2subscript𝐷2D_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} should remove the duplicate S1∩S2subscript𝑆1subscript𝑆2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\cap S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}. This should be done without harming each other's data privacy. Our solution applies private set intersection (PSI) which securely finds the intersection of S1subscript𝑆1S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and S2subscript𝑆2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} without revealing any other elements. Once D1subscript𝐷1D_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and D2subscript𝐷2D_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} learn S1∩S2subscript𝑆1subscript𝑆2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\cap S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} through PSI, D1subscript𝐷1D_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} will train on S1′=S1∖S1∩S2superscriptsubscript𝑆1′subscript𝑆1subscript𝑆1subscript𝑆2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}^{\prime}=S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\setminus S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\cap S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} and D2subscript𝐷2D_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} will train on S2subscript𝑆2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}. According to set theory, it holds that S1′∪S2=S1∪S2superscriptsubscript𝑆1′subscript𝑆2subscript𝑆1subscript𝑆2S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}^{\prime}\cup S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}=S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\cup S_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}. Hence, the resulting FL model remains as intended, while the training process is devoid of duplicates, avoiding the associated drawbacks. The scenario with two nodes seems straightforward. However, when more than two nodes participate, it becomes complicated. We now consider n𝑛n nodes D1,…,Dnsubscript𝐷1…subscript𝐷𝑛D_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,D_{\scriptscriptstyle n}, where each node Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{\scriptscriptstyle i} has a set Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}, ∀i,1≤i≤nfor-all𝑖1𝑖𝑛\forall i,1\leq i\leq n, and n>2𝑛2n>2.

Following the approach used in the two-node case, one might be tempted to (i) apply multi-party PSI to n𝑛n nodes, (ii) find their intersection Insubscript𝐼𝑛I_{\scriptscriptstyle n}, and (iii) let node D1subscript𝐷1D_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} train on S1′=S1∖Insuperscriptsubscript𝑆1′subscript𝑆1subscript𝐼𝑛S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}^{\prime}=S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\setminus I_{\scriptscriptstyle n}, and rest of the nodes train on their own dataset Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. This method removes the duplicates that exist across all the nodes. However, this does not detect and remove the duplicates that exist among a subset of nodes. For instance, if there is a subset of k𝑘k nodes (k<n𝑘𝑛k<n) with a large intersection Iksubscript𝐼𝑘I_{\scriptscriptstyle k}, then Iksubscript𝐼𝑘I_{\scriptscriptstyle k} will remain in the full training dataset S1′​⋃(⋃i=2nSi)superscriptsubscript𝑆1′superscriptsubscript𝑖2𝑛subscript𝑆𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}^{\prime}\bigcup(\bigcup\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=2}^{\scriptscriptstyle n}S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}) as duplicates. A generic multi-party PSI does not help in this case. Therefore, we need to consider each pair of nodes and remove the duplicates accordingly.

I-B Our Contributions

In this paper, our end goal is to develop a scheme such that allows multiple clients to benefit from deduplication while training on their data in a federated learning setup. The first requirement is an efficient deduplication of sets belonging to multiple clients. To address this, we introduce the notion of Privacy-Preserving Multi-Party Deduplication (P-MPD) in Section IV. This essentially describes a functionality that takes input datasets S1,…,Smsubscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑚S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,S_{\scriptscriptstyle m} (potentially containing duplicates) from m𝑚m clients and outputs the datasets S1′,…,Sm′superscriptsubscript𝑆1′…superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑚′S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}^{\prime},\ldots,S_{\scriptscriptstyle m}^{\prime} such that ⋃i=1mSi′=⋃i=1mSisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑆𝑖\bigcup\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle m}S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\prime}=\bigcup\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle m}S_{i}, where Si′∩Sj′=∅,i≠jformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗′𝑖𝑗S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\prime}\cap S_{\scriptscriptstyle j}^{\prime}=\emptyset,i\neq j. We realize that an efficient construction of P-MPD requires a substantially improved PSI protocol that supports scalability. This leads us to introduce a new notion for PSI which we call Group PSI (G-PSI) in Section III. The functionality of G-PSI takes sets from a group of clients and returns each client the intersection of their sets with all the other clients' sets. We provide constructions of Efficient Group PSI (EG-PSI) that efficiently realizes G-PSI, namely EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} in Figures 1 and 2, respectively. EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is based on symmetric key primitives such as pseudorandom permutation, while EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is developed using an oblivious pseudorandom function, which is a well-known public key primitive. With the building block EG-PSI, we build Efficient Privacy-Preserving Multi-Party Deduplication (EP-MPD) that realizes P-MPD as shown in Figure 4. We prove the security of EP-MPD, EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} within the simulation-based paradigm. Our construction of EP-MPD allows for efficient duplicate removal without compromising clients' data privacy, resulting in an improved model after running federated learning on the deduplicated datasets, as outlined in Figure 5.

We perform an extensive experimental evaluation to benchmark EP-MPD and the effect of the resulting deduplication on FL. The overall running time for EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, which employs EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} (symmetric key primitives based), is much less than EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, which utilizes EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} (public key primitives based). Overall, clients enjoy relatively less computation time in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. Our protocols can scale to large datasets and client counts. For example, when 50 clients have 219superscript2192^{\scriptscriptstyle 19} data points in their datasets comprising of 30%percent3030\% duplicates, then EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} takes 1160 seconds and EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} takes 7653 seconds; client running time is 641 and 111 seconds in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} respectively. We experiment with 7 datasets, 2 language models, and 10 clients in FL. We achieve an improvement of up to 19.61% in perplexity and up to 27.95% improvement in GPU training time.

II Preliminaries

II-A Notations and Assumptions

We define a wrapper function 𝚄𝚙𝚍𝚊𝚝𝚎​(S,S^)→S→𝚄𝚙𝚍𝚊𝚝𝚎𝑆^𝑆𝑆\mathtt{Update}(S,\hat{S})\rightarrow S which takes two sets, S𝑆S and S^^𝑆\hat{S}. It updates S𝑆S by removing from it the elements in set S^^𝑆\hat{S} and returns the updated set S𝑆S. In this paper, by the sum of sets (e.g., ∑i=1nSisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑆𝑖\sum\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle n}S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}) we mean the concatenation of the sets which may result in a multi-set. We denote an empty set by ∅\emptyset. We denote a size of vector v→→𝑣\vec{v} with |v→|→𝑣|\vec{v}|. We assume that the server and all the users have access to secure channels among them. By the notation, 𝒳≡c𝒴superscript𝑐𝒳𝒴\mathcal{X}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle c}}{{\equiv}}\mathcal{Y}, we mean that the two distributions 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} are computationally indistinguishable.

II-B Federated Learning (FL)

The concept of FL was proposed by McMahan et al. [38] as a framework for training an ML model where the training data are distributed across multiple devices. In FL, a server orchestrates the training of a global model by aggregating models locally computed by the clients on their local devices. Suppose there are n𝑛n clients, and each client Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{\scriptscriptstyle i} has a dataset Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. The server has the initial model 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta}. It sends 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta} to the clients, and each client performs gradient descent computation on their local dataset Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle i} as Ji​(Si,𝜽)=1di​∑(x,y)∈SiC​(𝜽,(x,y)),subscript𝐽𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖𝜽1subscript𝑑𝑖subscriptx𝑦subscript𝑆𝑖𝐶𝜽x𝑦J_{i}({S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i},\bm{\theta})=\frac{1}{d_{\scriptscriptstyle i}}\sum\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle(\textbf{x},y)\in{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}}C(\bm{\theta},(\textbf{x},y)), where C𝐶C is the cost function and di=|Si|subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖d_{\scriptscriptstyle i}=|{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}|. The client Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{\scriptscriptstyle i} computes the local models as 𝜽i←𝜽−η​∇J​(Si,𝜽),←subscript𝜽𝑖𝜽𝜂∇𝐽subscript𝑆𝑖𝜽\bm{\theta}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}\leftarrow\bm{\theta}-\eta\nabla J({S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i},\bm{\theta}), where η𝜂\eta is the learning rate. After receiving the local models from the clients, the server performs an aggregated averaging on the local models to derive the global model as:

Θ=1d​(d1​𝜽1+…+dn​𝜽n)Θ1𝑑subscript𝑑1subscript𝜽1…subscript𝑑𝑛subscript𝜽𝑛\Theta=\dfrac{1}{d}\big{(}d_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}\bm{\theta}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}+\ldots+d_{\scriptscriptstyle n}\bm{\theta}_{\scriptscriptstyle n}\big{)} (1)

where d=∑i=1ndi𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑑𝑖d=\sum\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle n}d_{\scriptscriptstyle i} is the total size of the dataset S=∑i=1nSi𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑆𝑖{S}=\sum\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle n}{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}, and 𝜽isubscript𝜽𝑖\bm{\theta}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} is the locally trained model on the dataset Sisubscript𝑆𝑖{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. This computation is repeated until the model converges.

While this framework achieves a basic level of privacy in which each user's data is not directly sent to the server, it is susceptible to advanced privacy attacks such as membership inference attacks [48, 37] and data extraction attacks [13, 46, 18, 4] as the client models θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{\scriptscriptstyle i} are aggregated in a non-private fashion on the server side. Some privacy-preserving FL protocols have attempted to mitigate these attacks by securely aggregating the client models. These protocols rely on cryptographic techniques like homomorphic encryption [14, 15], functional encryption [52], or secure aggregation [5, 9]. Additionally, differentially private training techniques [2] can be used to ensure differential privacy guarantees on the global model ΘΘ\Theta. We emphasize that in this paper, our proposed schemes are agnostic to the type of FL mechanism used.

II-C Causal Language Modeling (CLM)

Causal Language Modeling (CLM) is a natural language processing task where the goal of the language model is to predict the next word or token given a sequence of tokens. The language model autoregressively generates the next token until a pre-determined sequence length is reached or a special STOP token is generated. Given a sequence of n𝑛n tokens 𝐘={y1,y2​…,yn−1,yn}𝐘subscript𝑦1subscript𝑦2…subscript𝑦𝑛1subscript𝑦𝑛\mathbf{Y}=\{y_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},y_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}\ldots,y_{\scriptscriptstyle n-1},y_{\scriptscriptstyle n}\}, the language model ΘΘ\Theta is trained to learn the following probability distribution:

P​(𝐘)=∏i=1nP​(yi|y1,…,yi−1)𝑃𝐘superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛𝑃conditionalsubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑦1…subscript𝑦𝑖1P(\mathbf{Y})={\displaystyle\prod_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle n}P(y_{\scriptscriptstyle i}|y_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,y_{\scriptscriptstyle i-1})} (2)

The CLM training objective is to minimize the negative log-likelihood loss given by:

ℒ​(Θ,𝐘)=−∑i=1nlog⁡(Θ​(yi|y1,…,yi−1))ℒΘ𝐘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛Θconditionalsubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑦1…subscript𝑦𝑖1\mathcal{L}(\Theta,\mathbf{Y})=-\displaystyle\sum_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle n}\log(\Theta(y_{\scriptscriptstyle i}|y_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,y_{\scriptscriptstyle i-1})) (3)

After training is complete, the text is autoregressively sampled from the language model i.e., y^t<n∼Θ​(yt|y1,…,yt−1)similar-tosubscript^𝑦𝑡𝑛Θconditionalsubscript𝑦𝑡subscript𝑦1…subscript𝑦𝑡1\hat{y}_{\scriptscriptstyle t<n}\sim\Theta(y_{\scriptscriptstyle t}|y_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,y_{\scriptscriptstyle t-1}).

The perplexity metric is commonly used to evaluate the performance of the language model to determine how well it has learned the probability distribution in Equation 2. The perplexity P​P𝑃𝑃PP of a sequence 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} is defined as:

P​P​(𝐘)=exp⁡(−1n​∑i=1nlog⁡(Θ​(yi|y1,…,yi−1)))𝑃𝑃𝐘1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛Θconditionalsubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑦1…subscript𝑦𝑖1PP(\mathbf{Y})=\exp\left(-\frac{1}{n}{\displaystyle\sum_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle n}\log(\Theta(y_{\scriptscriptstyle i}|y_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,y_{\scriptscriptstyle i-1}))}\right) (4)

A lower perplexity score implies that model ΘΘ\Theta has been trained well to estimate the real-world probability distribution. Informally, a sequence with a low perplexity score implies that the model is less ``surprised'' by a sequence of tokens.

II-D Security Model

In this paper, we use the simulation-based paradigm of secure multi-party computation [21] to define and prove the proposed protocol. Since we focus on the static passive (semi-honest) adversarial model, we will restate the security definition within this context.

II-D1 Two-party Computation

A two-party protocol ΓΓ\Gamma is captured by specifying a random process that maps a pair of input to a pair of outputs (one output for each party). Such process is referred to as a functionality denoted by f:{0,1}∗×{0,1}∗→{0,1}∗×{0,1}∗:𝑓→superscript01superscript01superscript01superscript01f:\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle*}\times\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle*}\rightarrow\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle*}\times\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle*}, where f:=(f1,f2)assign𝑓subscript𝑓1subscript𝑓2f:=(f_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},f_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}). For every input pair (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y), the output pair is a random variable (f1​(x,y),f2​(x,y))subscript𝑓1𝑥𝑦subscript𝑓2𝑥𝑦(f_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}(x,y),f_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(x,y)), such that the party with input x𝑥x wishes to obtain f1​(x,y)subscript𝑓1𝑥𝑦f_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}(x,y) while the party with input y𝑦y wishes to receive f2​(x,y)subscript𝑓2𝑥𝑦f_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(x,y). The above functionality can be easily extended to more than two parties.

II-D2 Security in the Presence of Passive Adversaries

In the passive adversarial model, the party corrupted by such an adversary correctly follows the protocol specification. Nonetheless, the adversary obtains the internal state of the corrupted party, including the transcript of all the messages received, and tries to use this to learn information that should remain private. Loosely speaking, a protocol is secure if whatever can be computed by a corrupt party in the protocol can be computed using its input and output only.

In the simulation-based model, it is required that a party’s view in a protocol's execution can be simulated given only its input and output. This implies that the parties learn nothing from the protocol's execution. Formally, in two-party case, party i𝑖i’s view (during the execution of ΓΓ\Gamma) on input pair (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y) is denoted by 𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐iΓ​(x,y)superscriptsubscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝑖Γ𝑥𝑦\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\scriptscriptstyle\Gamma}(x,y) and equals (w,ri,m1i,…,mti)𝑤superscript𝑟𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑖…superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑡𝑖(w,r^{\scriptscriptstyle i},m_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}^{\scriptscriptstyle i},...,m_{\scriptscriptstyle t}^{\scriptscriptstyle i}), where w∈{x,y}𝑤𝑥𝑦w\in\{x,y\} is the input of it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{\scriptscriptstyle th} party, risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{\scriptscriptstyle i} is the outcome of this party's internal random coin tosses, and mjisuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑗𝑖m_{\scriptscriptstyle j}^{\scriptscriptstyle i} represents the jt​hsuperscript𝑗𝑡ℎj^{\scriptscriptstyle th} message this party receives. The output of the it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{\scriptscriptstyle th} party during the execution of ΓΓ\Gamma on (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y) is denoted by 𝖮𝗎𝗍𝗉𝗎𝗍iΓ​(x,y)superscriptsubscript𝖮𝗎𝗍𝗉𝗎𝗍𝑖Γ𝑥𝑦\mathsf{Output}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\scriptscriptstyle\Gamma}(x,y) and can be generated from its own view of the execution.

Definition 1.

Let f𝑓f be the deterministic functionality defined above. Protocol ΓΓ\Gamma securely computes f𝑓f in the presence of a static passive probabilistic polynomial-time (PPT) adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, if for every 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in the real model, there exist PPT algorithms (𝖲𝗂𝗆1,𝖲𝗂𝗆2)subscript𝖲𝗂𝗆1subscript𝖲𝗂𝗆2(\mathsf{Sim}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\mathsf{Sim}_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}) such that:
