Definition 1 can be easily extended to m>2𝑚2m>2 parties.

II-E Pseudorandom Function and Permutation

Informally, a pseudorandom function 𝙿𝚁𝙵(.)\mathtt{PRF}(.) is a deterministic function that takes a key of length λ𝜆\lambda and an input of length u𝑢u; and outputs a value of length v𝑣v indistinguishable from an output of a truly random function. More formally, a pseudorandom function can be defined as 𝙿𝚁𝙵:{0,1}λ×{0,1}u→{0,1}v:𝙿𝚁𝙵→superscript01𝜆superscript01𝑢superscript01𝑣\mathtt{PRF}:\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle\lambda}\times\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle u}\rightarrow\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle v}, where λ𝜆\lambda is the security parameter.

The definition of a pseudorandom permutation, 𝙿𝚁𝙿:{0,1}λ×{0,1}u→{0,1}u:𝙿𝚁𝙿→superscript01𝜆superscript01𝑢superscript01𝑢\mathtt{PRP}:\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle\lambda}\times\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle u}\rightarrow\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle u}, is very similar to that of a pseudorandom function, with a difference; namely, it is required the keyed function 𝙿𝚁𝙿​(k,⋅)𝙿𝚁𝙿𝑘⋅\mathtt{PRP}(k,\cdot) to be indistinguishable from a uniform permutation, instead of a uniform function. In cryptographic schemes that involve 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP}, sometimes honest parties may be required to compute the inverse of pseudorandom permutation, i.e., 𝙿𝚁𝙿−1​(k,⋅)superscript𝙿𝚁𝙿1𝑘⋅\mathtt{PRP}^{\scriptscriptstyle-1}(k,\cdot), as well. In this case, it would require that 𝙿𝚁𝙿​(k,⋅)𝙿𝚁𝙿𝑘⋅\mathtt{PRP}(k,\cdot) be indistinguishable from a uniform permutation even if the distinguisher is additionally given oracle access to the inverse of the permutation.

II-F Oblivious Pseudorandom Function

An Oblivious Pseudorandom Function (OPRF) is a protocol that involves a client and a server. OPRF enables the client with input x∈{0,1}u𝑥superscript01𝑢x\in\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle u}, and the server with key k∈{0,1}λ𝑘superscript01𝜆k\in\{0,1\}^{\scriptscriptstyle\lambda} to execute an instance of 𝙿𝚁𝙵𝙿𝚁𝙵\mathtt{PRF}. Informally, the security of an OPRF asserts that, by the completion of OPRF, the client only learns the output of 𝙿𝚁𝙵𝙿𝚁𝙵\mathtt{PRF} is evaluated on inputs k𝑘k and x𝑥x, i.e., 𝙿𝚁𝙵​(k,x)𝙿𝚁𝙵𝑘𝑥\mathtt{PRF}(k,x) while the server gains no information, e.g., about the input of the client and the output of 𝙿𝚁𝙵𝙿𝚁𝙵\mathtt{PRF}.

II-G Trusted Execution Environments

Trusted Execution Environment (𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}), also known as a secure enclave, constitutes a secure processing environment comprising processing, memory, and storage hardware units [41, 54]. Within this environment, the code and data residing in them remain isolated from other layers in the software stack, including the operating system. An ideal 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} guarantees the preservation of data integrity and confidentiality. Moreover, 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} can provide remote attestation capabilities, allowing a party to remotely verify the execution of an enclave on a genuine 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} hardware platform. Given the assumption that the physical CPU remains uncompromised, enclaves are shielded from attackers with physical access to the machine, including the memory and system bus.

Side-channel attacks on different deployments of 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}s have been demonstrated in the literature [49]. These attacks pose a threat as they could enable attackers to extract secrets from 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}s. Nevertheless, 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}s technologies have been evolving to address and mitigate side-channel attacks.

Our security, trust, and system assumptions regarding 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}s are conservative. Specifically, as detailed in Sections IV-B1 and III-B, our solution (i) avoids disclosing any plaintext messages or private keys to 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} and (ii) does not expect 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} to maintain an extensive storage and memory space or possess strong processing resources. Instead, we establish a formal model and construction under the assumption that 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} guarantees execution integrity (and authenticity), and ensures minimal confidentiality. Specifically, we formally demonstrate that 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} at the most only learns the size of the encrypted computation result (i.e., the intersections' cardinality). In our work, 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} can be seamlessly substituted with any semi-honest server that does not collude with other entities.

III Group PSI (G-PSI)

III-A Formal Definition of G-PSI

In this section, we present the concept of Group PSI (G-PSI). In G-PSI, there are two groups of clients, 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}, where each group contains m𝑚m clients, 𝒢j:{𝒞j,1,…,𝒞j,m}:subscript𝒢𝑗subscript𝒞𝑗1…subscript𝒞𝑗𝑚\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle j}:\{\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,1},\ldots,\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,m}\}, 0≤j≤10𝑗10\leq j\leq 1. Each client 𝒞j,1subscript𝒞𝑗1\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,1} has a set Sj,1subscript𝑆𝑗1{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,1}, such that no pair of clients' sets in the same group share a common element.

Informally, G-PSI allows every client in one group to (efficiently) find the intersection that their set has with the set of every client of the other group, without allowing them to learn anything beyond that about other clients' set elements. To achieve a high level of computational efficiency in G-PSI, we will involve a third-party 𝒯​𝒫𝒯𝒫\mathcal{TP} that assists the clients with computing the intersection. The functionality fG-PSIsubscript𝑓G-PSI{f}_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}} that G-PSI computes takes a set Sj,isubscript𝑆𝑗𝑖{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} from every client 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} and no input from 𝒯​𝒫𝒯𝒫\mathcal{TP}. It returns (i) to every client 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} a vector v→j,isubscript→𝑣𝑗𝑖\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} which contains the intersection that 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}'s set has with every other client's set in the other group and (ii) to 𝒯​𝒫𝒯𝒫\mathcal{TP} an empty set ∅\emptyset. Hence, functionality fG-PSIsubscript𝑓G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}} can be formally defined as follows.

fG-PSI​((S0,1,…,S0,m⏟𝒢0),(S1,1,…,S1,m⏟𝒢1),∅)→((v→0,1,…,v→0,m⏟𝒢0),(v→1,1,…,v→1,m⏟𝒢1),∅),→subscript𝑓G-PSIsubscript⏟subscript𝑆01…subscript𝑆0𝑚subscript𝒢0subscript⏟subscript𝑆11…subscript𝑆1𝑚subscript𝒢1subscript⏟subscript→𝑣01…subscript→𝑣0𝑚subscript𝒢0subscript⏟subscript→𝑣11…subscript→𝑣1𝑚subscript𝒢1\begin{split}f_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}}\Big{(}(\underbrace{{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0}}),(\underbrace{{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}}),\emptyset\Big{)}\rightarrow\\ \Big{(}(\underbrace{\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0}}),(\underbrace{\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}}),\emptyset\Big{)},\end{split} (5)

where, v→j,i=[[Sj,i∩S1−j,1],…,[Sj,i∩S1−j,m]]subscript→𝑣𝑗𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖subscript𝑆1𝑗1…delimited-[]subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖subscript𝑆1𝑗𝑚\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}=\Big{[}[{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}\cap{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1-j,1}],\ldots,[{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}\cap{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1-j,m}]\Big{]}, 0≤j≤10𝑗10\leq j\leq 1, and 1≤i≤m1𝑖𝑚1\leq i\leq m.

In the case where clients of only one of the groups, e.g., 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0}, receives the result, then the above functionality simply returns ∅\emptyset to the clients in the other group, e.g., v→1,1=…=v→1,m=∅subscript→𝑣11…subscript→𝑣1𝑚{\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1}=\ldots=\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m}}=\emptyset.

Since 𝒯​𝒫𝒯𝒫\mathcal{TP} performs computation on all clients' encrypted sets, there is a possibility of leakage to 𝒯​𝒫𝒯𝒫\mathcal{TP}. Depending on the protocol that realizes fG-PSIsubscript𝑓G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}} this leakage could contain different types of information; for instance, it could contain (i) the size of the intersection of any two clients' sets, or (ii) the size of the intersection of all clients' sets, or (iii) nothing at all. Often such leakage is defined by a leakage function ℒℒ\mathcal{L} that takes all parties (encoded) inputs and returns the amount of leakage.

We assert that a protocol securely realizes fG-PSIsubscript𝑓G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}} if (1) it reveals nothing beyond a predefined leakage to 𝒯​𝒫𝒯𝒫\mathcal{TP} and (2) whatever can be computed by a client in the protocol can be obtained from its input and output. This is formalized under the simulation paradigm. We require a client’s view during an execution of G-PSI to be simulatable given its input and output. We require that the view of 𝒯​𝒫𝒯𝒫\mathcal{TP} can be simulated given the leakage.

Definition 2 (Security of G-PSI).

Let 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} be two groups of clients, where each group contains m𝑚m clients, 𝒢j:{𝒞j,1,…,𝒞j,m}:subscript𝒢𝑗subscript𝒞𝑗1…subscript𝒞𝑗𝑚\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle j}:\{\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,1},\ldots,\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,m}\}, 0≤j≤10𝑗10\leq j\leq 1. Let ℒℒ\mathcal{L} denote a leakage function, fG-PSIsubscript𝑓G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}} be the functionality defined above (in Relation 5 on page 5), S={S0,1,…,S=\{{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots, S0,m,S1,1,…,S1,m}{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m},{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m}\}, and Sj,isubscript𝑆𝑗𝑖{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} represent a set belonging to client 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}. Then, a protocol ΓΓ\Gamma securely realizes fG-PSIsubscript𝑓G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}} in the presence of a static semi-honest PPT adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, if for every 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in the real model, there exists a PPT adversary (simulator) 𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝗂𝗆\mathsf{Sim} in the ideal model, such that for every 𝒞j,i∈{𝒞0,1,…,𝒞0,m,𝒞1,1,…,𝒞1,m}subscript𝒞𝑗𝑖subscript𝒞01…subscript𝒞0𝑚subscript𝒞11…subscript𝒞1𝑚\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}\in\{\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m},\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m}\} and 𝒯​𝒫𝒯𝒫\mathcal{TP}, Relations 6 and 7 hold respectively.

{𝖲𝗂𝗆𝒞j,i​(Sj,i,v→j,i)}S≡c{𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝒞j,i𝒜,Γ​(S,∅)}Ssuperscript𝑐subscriptsubscript𝖲𝗂𝗆subscript𝒞𝑗𝑖subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖subscript→𝑣𝑗𝑖𝑆subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐subscript𝒞𝑗𝑖𝒜Γ𝑆𝑆\{\mathsf{Sim}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}}({S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i},\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i})\}_{\scriptscriptstyle S}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle c}}{{\equiv}}\{\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{A},\Gamma}(S,\emptyset)\}_{\scriptscriptstyle S} (6)
{𝖲𝗂𝗆𝒯​𝒫ℒ​(∅,∅)}S≡c{𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝒯​𝒫𝒜,Γ​(S,∅)}Ssuperscript𝑐subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆ℒ𝒯𝒫𝑆subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝒯𝒫𝒜Γ𝑆𝑆\{\mathsf{Sim}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{L}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{TP}}(\emptyset,\emptyset)\}_{\scriptscriptstyle S}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle c}}{{\equiv}}\{\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{TP}}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{A},\Gamma}(S,\emptyset)\}_{\scriptscriptstyle S} (7)

where v→j,i=[[Sj,i∩S1−j,1],…,[Sj,i∩S1−j,m]]subscript→𝑣𝑗𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖subscript𝑆1𝑗1…delimited-[]subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖subscript𝑆1𝑗𝑚\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}=\Big{[}[{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}\cap{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1-j,1}],\ldots,[{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}\cap{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1-j,m}]\Big{]}, 0≤j≤10𝑗10\leq j\leq 1, 1≤i≤m1𝑖𝑚1\leq i\leq m, and 𝒯​𝒫𝒯𝒫\mathcal{TP}'s input is ∅\emptyset.

III-B Efficient Construction of G-PSI

In this section, we introduce two efficient protocols that realize G-PSI. The first one, called EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, is highly efficient and based on symmetric key cryptography. The second one, called EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, is based on OPRF (in turn depends on public key cryptography) and discloses less information to 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} than the former does. Thus, these two protocols trade-off between performance and leakage amount.

III-B1 EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}

At a high level, EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} operates as follows. Initially, each client in group 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} agrees with every client in group 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} on a secret key. Every client encrypts its set elements using every key it has agreed on with other clients (in a different group).

Each client, for every encrypted set element, temporally stores a triple that includes (i) the encrypted element, (ii) the key used to encrypt that element, and (iii) the index of the client with whom the key was shared. These triples will enable the client to efficiently (a) retrieve the correct key and (b) identify the client with whom it has the element in common when presented with an encrypted element. Once all elements are encrypted using the corresponding keys, each client transmits only its encrypted elements to 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}.

Given the sets of encrypted elements from all clients, 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} aggregates these sets and identifies the encrypted elements that appear more than once. Subsequently, 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} forwards to a client those encrypted elements that (1) appear more than once and (2) are among the messages that the client initially sent to 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}. Upon receiving each encrypted element from 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}, a client searches its local list of triples to locate the corresponding key and the index l𝑙l representing a specific client. Utilizing the key, the client decrypts the element and regards the resultant element as one of the elements within the intersection it shares with the l𝑙l-th client. For a comprehensive description of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, refer to Figure 1.

The only information that 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} learns in EG-PSI is the size of the intersection of any two clients' sets, called pair-wise intersection cardinality. Below, we formally define it.

Definition 3 (pair-wise intersection cardinality).

Let (S0,1′,…,S0,m′⏟𝒢0),subscript⏟subscriptsuperscript𝑆′01…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′0𝑚subscript𝒢0(\underbrace{{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0}}), (S1,1′,…,S1,m′⏟𝒢1)subscript⏟subscriptsuperscript𝑆′11…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′1𝑚subscript𝒢1(\underbrace{{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}}) be two groups 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} of (encrypted) sets. Then, vector s→→𝑠\vec{s} represents the pair-wise intersection cardinality: s→=[s→0,1,…,\vec{s}=[\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots, s→0,m,s→1,1,…,s→1,m]\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m},\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m}], where s→j,i=[|[Sj,i∩S1−j,1]|,…,|[Sj,i∩S1−j,m]|]subscript→𝑠𝑗𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖subscript𝑆1𝑗1…delimited-[]subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖subscript𝑆1𝑗𝑚\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}=\Big{[}\big{|}[{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}\cap{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1-j,1}]\big{|},\ldots,\big{|}[{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}\cap{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1-j,m}]\big{|}\Big{]}, 0≤j≤10𝑗10\leq j\leq 1, and 1≤i≤m1𝑖𝑚1\leq i\leq m.

Definition 4.

Let s→→𝑠\vec{s} be a pair-wise intersection cardinality of two groups 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} of encrypted sets: (S0,1′,…,S0,m′⏟𝒢0),(S1,1′,…,S1,m′⏟𝒢1)subscript⏟subscriptsuperscript𝑆′01…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′0𝑚subscript𝒢0subscript⏟subscriptsuperscript𝑆′11…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′1𝑚subscript𝒢1(\underbrace{{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0}}),(\underbrace{{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}}), with respect to Definition 3. Then, leakage function ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is defined as follows: ℒ​((S0,1′,…,S0,m′),(S1,1′,…,S1,m′))→s→→ℒsubscriptsuperscript𝑆′01…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′0𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑆′11…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′1𝑚→𝑠\mathcal{L}\Big{(}({S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m}),({S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m})\Big{)}\rightarrow\vec{s}.

Theorem 1.

Let fG-PSIsubscript𝑓G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}} be the functionality defined in Relation 5. Also, let ℒℒ\mathcal{L} be the leakage function presented in Definition 4. If 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP} is a secure pseudorandom permutation, then EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} (presented in Figure 1) securely realizes fG-PSIsubscript𝑓G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}}, with respect to Definition 2.

We refer to Appendix -A for the proof of Theorem 1.

III-B2 EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}

In this section, we present EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} which is the second variant of EG-PSI. Note that 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} in EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is able to learn the cardinality of the intersection of each pair of clients' sets. We aim to reduce this leakage in EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. However, EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is no longer based on symmetric key cryptography as it depends on OPRF. To the best of our knowledge, all the constructions of OPRFs are based on public key cryptography whose security depends on some hard problem assumptions. The same holds for EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}.

A brief overview of the construction of EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is as follows. We have two groups of clients 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} having their own set that they want to find the pairwise intersection. There is a 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} that has a key k𝑘k for a 𝙿𝚁𝙵𝙿𝚁𝙵\mathtt{PRF}. During the setup, each client interacts with 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} to encrypt their set using 𝙿𝚁𝙵​(k,⋅)𝙿𝚁𝙵𝑘⋅\mathtt{PRF}(k,\cdot) through an OPRF call. Then, each client of group 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} will send their encrypted set to every client of 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0}. Upon receiving an encrypted set from a client of 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}, each client of 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} determines the intersection with their encrypted set. Once the client finds the intersection, it marks the index of the elements in the intersection and consider the elements with the same index in the unencrypted set as elements in the intersection. Similarly, each client of 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} shares their encrypted set with each client of 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and follows the same steps. Ultimately, every client of 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} knows the intersection between their set and all the sets belonging to the clients of 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}, and the other way around. We give a detailed description of EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} in Figure 2.

In EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} does not participate in the protocol except the OPRF evaluation and that is also a one-time activity. As a result, 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} does not learn anything about the set intersection, it only learns the cardinality of each client's set.

Theorem 2.

Let fG-PSIsubscript𝑓G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}} be the functionality defined in Relation 5 (on page 5). Also, let ℒℒ\mathcal{L} be the leakage function presented in Definition 4 with the empty output. If OPRF is secure, then EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} securely realizes fG-PSIsubscript𝑓G-PSIf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{G-PSI}}, w.r.t. Definition 2.

Appendix -B outlines the proof of Theorem 2. Note that both variants remain secure in the presence of semi-honest adversaries. However, if 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} or a client is a malicious (or active) adversary, then it can affect the correctness of the result, without being detected.

IV Privacy-Preserving Multi-Party Deduplication (P-MPD)

IV-A Formal Definition of P-MPD

P-MPD considers the setting where there are n𝑛n clients C={𝒞1,…,𝒞m}𝐶subscript𝒞1…subscript𝒞𝑚C=\{\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle m}\} and each 𝒞i∈Csubscript𝒞𝑖𝐶\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}\in C has a set Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. P-MPD enables the clients to (efficiently) remove duplicates from their local sets such that after the deduplication the concatenation of all clients' local sets equals the union of their initial sets.

The functionality fP-MPDsubscript𝑓P-MPDf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}} that P-MPD computes takes a set Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle i} from each 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. It returns an updated (i.e., deduplicated) set Si′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑖S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} to each 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. Formerly, fP-MPDsubscript𝑓P-MPDf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}} can be defined as follows:

fP-MPD​(S1,…,Sm)→(S1′,…,Sm′),→subscript𝑓P-MPDsubscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑆′1…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑚f_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}}(S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,S_{\scriptscriptstyle m})\rightarrow(S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle m}), (8)

where ∑i=1mSi′=⋃i=1mSi=S∪subscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑖1subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑆\sum\limits^{\scriptscriptstyle m}_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}=\bigcup\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle m}S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}=S_{\scriptscriptstyle\cup} and S∪subscript𝑆S_{\cup} denotes the union of all initial sets and contains only unique elements.

To maintain generality, we define a leakage function, denoted as 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W}. The output of this function relies on the protocol implementing fP-MPDsubscript𝑓P-MPDf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}}. We assert that a protocol securely realizes fP-MPDsubscript𝑓P-MPDf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}} if whatever can be computed by a party in the protocol can be derived solely from its individual input and output, given the output of 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W}. Below, we formally state it.

Definition 5 (Security of P-MPD).

Let S={S1,…,Sm}𝑆subscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑚S=\{{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle m}\}, and Sisubscript𝑆𝑖{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} represent a set belonging to client 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. Let 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} denote a leakage function and fP-MPDsubscript𝑓P-MPDf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}} be the functionality defined in Relation 8. Then, a protocol ΨΨ\Psi securely realizes fP-MPDsubscript𝑓P-MPDf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}} in the presence of a static semi-honest PPT adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, if for every 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in the real model, there exists a PPT 𝖲𝗂𝗆𝖲𝗂𝗆\mathsf{Sim} in the ideal model, such that for every 𝒞i∈{𝒞1,…,𝒞m}subscript𝒞𝑖subscript𝒞1…subscript𝒞𝑚\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}\in\{\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle m}\}, Relation 9 holds.

{𝖲𝗂𝗆𝒞i𝒲​(Si,Si′)}S≡c{𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝒞i𝒜,Ψ​(S)}S.superscript𝑐subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆𝒲subscript𝒞𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑖𝑆subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐subscript𝒞𝑖𝒜Ψ𝑆𝑆\{\mathsf{Sim}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{W}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}}({S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i},{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle i})\}_{\scriptscriptstyle S}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle c}}{{\equiv}}\{\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{A},\Psi}(S)\}_{\scriptscriptstyle S}. (9)

IV-B Constructions of P-MPD

IV-B1 Construction Based on EG-PSI

We introduce a pioneering protocol called Efficient Privacy-Preserving Multi-Party Deduplication (EP-MPD) that realizes P-MPD efficiently. The idea behind EP-MPD's design involves constructing a binary tree with leaf nodes representing the clients’ indices. At each level, each cluster is formed with two different groups of clients, namely 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}. Subsequently, EG-PSI is recursively applied to the sets of clients sharing the same cluster until the tree's root is reached. After each invocation of EG-PSI, the clients of 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} update their sets by removing the intersections, returned by EG-PSI, from their local sets. These updated sets are then used as input in the subsequent EG-PSI invocation.

Next, we delve into further detail. We begin by sorting the clients' indices in ascending order. Next, we construct a binary tree such that the leaf nodes represent the clients' indices.

At level d=1𝑑1d=1, commencing from the left-hand side, every two clients form a cluster. Within each cluster, the first client is assigned to group 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and the second client to group 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}. Then, the clients within the same cluster engage in an instance of EG-PSI. Upon the return of the sets' intersection by EG-PSI, only the client situated on the left-hand side, specifically the one with the smaller index, modifies its local set by eliminating the elements of the intersection from its sets. This process is outlined in Figure 3(a).

At level d=2𝑑2d=2, starting from the left-hand side, every set of 2dsuperscript2𝑑2^{\scriptscriptstyle d} clients form a cluster. Within each cluster, the initial 2d2=2superscript2𝑑22\frac{2^{\scriptscriptstyle d}}{2}=2 clients enter group 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and the remainder (i.e., the remaining 222 clients) enter group 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}. Subsequently, the clients within the same cluster engage in an instance of EG-PSI. Once again, upon the return of their sets' intersection by EG-PSI, the clients possessing the smaller indices update their local sets. This procedure is illustrated in Figure 3(b).

The process continues until level d=log2⁡m𝑑subscript2𝑚d=\log_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}{m} is reached. At this point, all m𝑚m clients collectively engage in an instance of EG-PSI. Each 2d2=m2superscript2𝑑2𝑚2\frac{2^{\scriptscriptstyle d}}{2}=\frac{m}{2} clients enter group 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and the remaining m2𝑚2\frac{m}{2} clients enter group 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}. These m𝑚m clients jointly participate in an instance of EG-PSI. Similarly to previous steps, the clients with the smaller indices update their local sets based on the output of EG-PSI. This procedure is outlined in Figure 3(c).

Figure 4 presents a detailed description of EP-MPD. For the sake of simplicity, we assume that m𝑚m is a power of 2 in EP-MPD's description. However, we do not impose on the number of clients. Non-powers of 2 will result in incomplete sub-trees in the formation of clusters in the DE protocol where each group may have an unequal number of clients. This does not affect the EP-MPD protocol execution.

IV-C Naive Approaches

IV-C1 Running a Two-Party PSI Multiple Times

One might be tempted to allow each client to invoke an existing two-party PSI with every other client. However, this approach in total requires (m2)=O​(m2)binomial𝑚2𝑂superscript𝑚2{m\choose 2}=O(m^{\scriptscriptstyle 2}) invocations of the two-party PSI. Whereas EP-MPD requires only ∑i=1log2⁡(m)(m2i)=m−1subscriptsuperscriptsubscript2𝑚𝑖1𝑚superscript2𝑖𝑚1\sum\limits^{\scriptscriptstyle\log_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(m)}_{\scriptscriptstyle i=1}(\frac{m}{2^{\scriptscriptstyle i}})=m-1 invocations of our efficient tailor-made PSI, EG-PSI. To provide concrete values, when m=256𝑚256m=256, the naive scheme requires 32,640 invocations of a standard two-party PSI, whereas our scheme requires only 255255255 invocations of EG-PSI.

IV-C2 Running Multi-Party PSI Once

One might be tempted to execute an existing multi-party PSI protocol only once on all clients' sets, hoping to identify and subsequently remove duplicated elements. Nevertheless, this approach falls short of identifying all duplications. The limitation arises from the fact that a multi-party PSI can uncover elements common to all clients, making it incapable of detecting elements shared among only a subset of clients.

IV-C3 Deduplicating all Sets at Once

There is a simplified version of EP-MPD. In this variant, each client reaches an agreement with the others on a secret key. Subsequently, each client encrypts its set elements using every key agreed upon with the other clients. Finally, all clients transmit their encrypted set elements to 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}. Upon receiving the encrypted sets from all clients, 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} identifies all duplicated elements. It then transmits to each client: (1) the duplicated elements found in the original elements that the respective client sent to 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}, and (2) the index of the client with which it shares the same element. Based on 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}'s response, the clients with smaller indices update their local sets accordingly.

However, this approach requires that 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} maintains a local storage or memory space equal to the size of the concatenation of all encrypted sets. In contrast, EP-MPD with the underlying EG-PSI building block, allows 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} to have a substantially smaller storage or memory space. This is achieved because, before 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} receives all clients' encrypted sets at level d=l​o​g2​(m)𝑑𝑙𝑜subscript𝑔2𝑚d=log_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(m), clients apply updates to their sets multiple times. This iterative process progressively reduces the size of the clients' sets, and the reduction can be particularly significant when the number of duplications is substantial.

IV-D Security Analysis

In any secure (multi-party) deduplication protocol, a participating client will learn the exact redundant elements within its set upon the protocol's completion. However, in EP-MPD, a client gains slightly more information. To be specific, upon the completion of EP-MPD, each client acquires the knowledge of the index (or identity) of the client that shares the redundant element. This additional information gained by a client during the execution of EP-MPD is formally defined as the output of a leakage function 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} which we define below.

𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} takes as input (i) sets S1,…,Smsubscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑚{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle m}, where each set Sisubscript𝑆𝑖{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} belongs to client 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}, and (ii) sets R1,…,Rmsubscript𝑅1…subscript𝑅𝑚R_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,R_{\scriptscriptstyle m}, where each Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{\scriptscriptstyle i} contains the redundancy (or intersection) that a set Sisubscript𝑆𝑖{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} has with every other set. 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} outputs to the i𝑖i-th client a set Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{\scriptscriptstyle i} of triples, where each triple is of the form (ri,l,i,l)subscript𝑟𝑖𝑙𝑖𝑙(r_{\scriptscriptstyle i,l},i,l), ri,l∈Risubscript𝑟𝑖𝑙subscript𝑅𝑖r_{\scriptscriptstyle i,l}\in R_{\scriptscriptstyle i} is a redundancy between sets Sisubscript𝑆𝑖{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} and Slsubscript𝑆𝑙{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle l}.

Definition 6.

Let S={S1,…,Sm}𝑆subscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑚S=\{{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle m}\} be a set of sets, where each set Sisubscript𝑆𝑖{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} belongs to client 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. Also, let R={R1,…,Rm}𝑅subscript𝑅1…subscript𝑅𝑚R=\{R_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,R_{\scriptscriptstyle m}\} be a set of sets, where each set Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{\scriptscriptstyle i} comprises the redundancy that Sisubscript𝑆𝑖{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} has with every other j𝑗j-th set, for all j𝑗j, 1≤j≤m1𝑗𝑚1\leq j\leq m and i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j. Then, leakage function 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} is defined as follows: 𝒲​(S,R)→(Q1,…,Qm)→𝒲𝑆𝑅subscript𝑄1…subscript𝑄𝑚\mathcal{W}(S,R)\rightarrow(Q_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,Q_{\scriptscriptstyle m}), where each Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{\scriptscriptstyle i} is a set of triples of the form (ri,l,i,l)subscript𝑟𝑖𝑙𝑖𝑙(r_{\scriptscriptstyle i,l},i,l), ri,l∈Risubscript𝑟𝑖𝑙subscript𝑅𝑖r_{\scriptscriptstyle i,l}\in R_{\scriptscriptstyle i} is a redundancy between sets Sisubscript𝑆𝑖{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} and Slsubscript𝑆𝑙{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle l}.

Theorem 3.

Let fP-MPDsubscript𝑓P-MPDf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}} be the functionality defined in Relation 8 and 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} be the leakage function presented in Definition 6. If EG-PSI is secure (w.r.t. Definition 2), then EP-MPD (presented in Figure 4) securely realizes fP-MPDsubscript𝑓P-MPDf_{\scriptscriptstyle\text{P-MPD}}, w.r.t. Definition 5.

The proof of Theorem 3 can be found in Appendix -C.

V Enhanced FL: Applying EP-MPD to FL

With all essential building blocks in place, we are prepared to elucidate the complete functionality of the system. There are clients 𝒞1,…,𝒞msubscript𝒞1…subscript𝒞𝑚\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle m} having the sets S1,…,Smsubscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑚{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle m}, where each Sisubscript𝑆𝑖{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} belongs to client 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} respectively. Phase 1 involves each client conducting local deduplication. Since the local deduplication is a private computation there is no privacy requirement. The data owners can apply deduplication techniques as illustrated in [31] which results in having a set Si′superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖′{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\prime} free of duplicates by each client 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}. Subsequently, in Phase 2 they employ EP-MPD to eliminate duplicates across all clients. At the end of this phase, client 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} gets an updated set Si′′superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖′′{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\prime\prime}, such that ∑i=1mSi′′=⋃i=1mSi′.superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖′′superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖′\sum\limits_{i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle m}{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\prime\prime}=\bigcup\limits_{i=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle m}{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}^{\prime}. Moving to Phase 3, they adopt a FL protocol (outlined in Section II-B) to train the model. Further details of this procedure are provided in Figure 5.

VI Experiments

VI-A Implementation Details

We implement the EP-MPD protocol in python=3.10. We use AES with a 128-bit key in CBC mode from the cryptography library as a PRP in EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}. To realize an OPRF in EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, we use the OPRF algorithm proposed in [11] from the oprf library. All EP-MPD experiments are conducted on a batch computing facility with a Dual Intel Xeon E5-2660 v3 @ 2.6 GHz CPU and 60 GB RAM.

For the FL experiments, we implement a FL setting for CLMs using python=3.10 with the transformers=4.40.1 and torch=2.3 libraries. We implement the FedAvg [38] algorithm for FL training to analyze the effect of EP-MPD on FL's performance. However, in practice, we recommend combining EP-MPD with privacy-preserving FL protocols for end-to-end privacy guarantees. All FL experiments are conducted on a server with an Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6336Y CPU @ 2.40GHz CPU and NVIDIA RTX A6000 GPU.

We run all clients sequentially on a machine for both experiments. However, to emulate a real-world setting where clients run on different devices at the same time, we first compute the individual client running times and then estimate the real-world distributed running time by assuming the clients have run simultaneously. We open-source our implementations111https://github.com/vdasu/deduplication.

While implementing EP-MPD, we have two options for the EG-PSI module: EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. We observe that EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}-based EP-MPD calls an OPRF function for every client in the leaf nodes of the EP-MPD tree, returning an encryption of the clients' sets. As clients move to upper levels, their set elements remain unchanged, with only the cardinality potentially changing. Therefore, except at the bottom level, OPRF calls are unnecessary for encryption, allowing the same encrypted set or their subsets to be reused at other levels. Thus, we have slightly adjusted the implementation. This significantly reduces time without compromising security properties, as reflected in our experiments.

VI-B EP-MPD Benchmarks

VI-B1 Experimental Setup

We designed three experiment settings to benchmark the performance of EP-MPD. The three settings analyze the effect of the number of clients, dataset size, and duplication percentage on the runtime of EP-MPD. All experiments were performed with both EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} as building blocks. The duplication percentage refers to the percentage of samples in a client's dataset present in another client's dataset. The three experiment settings are:

  1. a.

    The dataset size is fixed at |Si|=219subscript𝑆𝑖superscript219|S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}|=2^{\scriptscriptstyle 19}, the duplication percentage at 30%percent3030\%, while the number of clients m𝑚m is varied. Specifically, m𝑚m is set to each value in {10,20,30,40,50}1020304050\{10,20,30,40,50\}.

  2. b.

    The number of clients is fixed at 505050 and the duplication percentage at 30%percent3030\%, while the dataset size |Si|subscript𝑆𝑖|S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}| is varied. Specifically, |Si|subscript𝑆𝑖|S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}| is set to each value in {210,211,213,215,217,219}superscript210superscript211superscript213superscript215superscript217superscript219\{2^{\scriptscriptstyle 10},2^{\scriptscriptstyle 11},2^{\scriptscriptstyle 13},2^{\scriptscriptstyle 15},2^{\scriptscriptstyle 17},2^{\scriptscriptstyle 19}\}.

  3. c.

    The database size |Si|subscript𝑆𝑖|S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}| is fixed at 219superscript2192^{\scriptscriptstyle 19}, the number of clients at 505050, while the duplication percentage is varied. Specifically, it is set to each value in {10%,30%,50%,70%,90%}percent10percent30percent50percent70percent90\{10\%,30\%,50\%,70\%,90\%\}.

We create pairwise duplicates between clients such that every client has a unique duplicate element with every other client. All set elements are 32-bit integers. We assume that the 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} can receive data in parallel from the clients. All other interactions that require computation between 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} and clients occur sequentially. In the remainder of this section, by EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} we mean the EP-MPD that uses EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} respectively.

VI-B2 Effect of Client Count

Figure 6 depicts the effect of the number of clients on (a) EP-MPD running time, (b) the average running time of clients, and (c) 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} running time. Figure 6(a) demonstrates that the EP-MPD running time increases linearly with the number of clients for both EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. The increase in the client count rises the number of PRP and OPRF evaluations as the total number of elements across all clients grows. We observe that EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is about 7–10×7\mbox{--}10\times faster than EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}.

The average running time of the client however shows a different trend. The client running time in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} increases linearly with the client count and is always greater than – up to 6×6\times – the running time of EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. The running time of EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is constant as the number of clients increases. In EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, the client-side running time increases with the number of clients, because each client has to perform more PRP evaluations. However, in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, the number of OPRF evaluations is equal to the number of elements in each client's set. Additionally, in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, the clients perform the PRP evaluations at every level of the tree. However, in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} the OPRF evaluations are only performed once when the clients are at the leaf level.

The running time of 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} follows a similar trend to the EP-MPD running time. The 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} running time in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is always higher than EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}. Both exhibit linear increases in running time as the number of clients increases. The running time in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is much higher as the OPRF evaluations are relatively expensive.

VI-B3 Effect of Dataset Size

Figure 7 illustrates the effect of dataset size on EP-MPD running time, the average running time of clients, and 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} running time. From Figure 7(a), it is evident that the EP-MPD running time grows linearly with increasing the dataset size. EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is up to 8×8\times faster than EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. As the dataset size increases, the number of PRP and OPRF evaluations grows, thereby increasing the EP-MPD running time.

Figure 7(b) shows the effect of dataset size on client running time. Unlike increasing the client count, increasing the dataset size increases the client running time of both EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. We observe this difference because an increase in dataset size increases the number of OPRF evaluations while any change in the client count does not. The client running time of EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is up to 7×7\times faster than EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}.

Figure 7(c) depicts the effect of dataset size on the running time of 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}. The growth of dataset size increases the OPRF evaluations in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. In EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} has to identify more overlapping ciphertexts as the datasets are larger. The running time of 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} increases linearly with the dataset size for both cases. 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} running time in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is up to 5×5\times faster than EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}.

VI-B4 Effect of Duplication Percentage

Figure 8 shows the effect of duplication percentage on EP-MPD running time, the average running time of clients, and 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} running time. Figure 8(a) highlights the running time of EP-MPD as the duplication percentage changes. We note that in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, OPRF evaluations incur the most overwhelming running time, dominating all other running time costs. Overall, the running time of EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is constant while that of EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} linearly decreases as the duplication rate grows. In EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, the number of OPRF evaluations is independent of the duplication percentage, because the OPRF is always performed only when the clients are at the leaf level. However, in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, the number of PRP invocations decreases as clients move up the tree from the leaf level because a higher duplication percentage removes more elements in each level of the tree. The total running time of EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is up to 7×7\times faster than EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}.

Furthermore, the client-side running time of EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is constant while that of EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} linearly decreases as the duplication percentage increases, as shown in Figure 8(b). The reason is identical to the observation of the EP-MPD running time. The number of PRP evaluations reduces while the number of OPRF evaluations does not. Similar to the prior experiment settings, the client time of EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is higher than EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} and is up to 7×7\times slower. Figure 8(c) shows the effect of duplication percentage on the running time of 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}. The 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} running time in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is constant while in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} linearly decreases. The 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} running time in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is up to 2×2\times faster than EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}.

The overall running time of the symmetric key-based EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is considerably less than the public key-based EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. Nevertheless, the clients in EP-MPD(I)superscriptEP-MPDI\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} need to perform more computations compared to those in EP-MPD(II)superscriptEP-MPDII\text{EP-MPD}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}.

VI-C FL with EP-MPD

VI-C1 Experimental Setup

We create an FL setting with varying levels of duplication to analyze the effect of EP-MPD on the model performance and training efficiency of CLM fine-tuning. We use GPT-2 Medium and GPT-2 Large CLMs from the GPT-2 [43] family of decoder-only models based on the Transformer [50] architecture. The GPT-2 Medium has 345 million parameters with 24 decoder blocks, 16 attention heads, and 1024 hidden sizes while GPT-2 Large has 774 million parameters with 36 decoder blocks, 20 attention heads, and 1280 hidden sizes. Both models have a sequence length of 1024 tokens.

We create 10 clients and experiment with the following 7 datasets. The Rotten Tomatoes and IMDB datasets contain movie reviews. The Sonnets and Plays datasets are a collection of works by William Shakespeare. Poetry is a collection of short poems by a variety of poets. Haiku and Short Jokes are a collection of short Japanese-style poems and Jokes from Reddit respectively. The language modeling task for each dataset is to learn how to generate text from the dataset's distribution. For all datasets, we create a Train and Test split in an 80:20 ratio. Model perplexity is evaluated on the Test set after training. We follow a two-step procedure to create the client datasets with x%percent𝑥x\% duplication. Initially, we equally distributed the Train set among all 10 clients. Next, we sample with replacement x%percent𝑥x\% of the original Train set. This subset is then again equally distributed among all clients. We perform 5 rounds of FL training with at most 10 epochs of local training. The GPT-2 Large models were trained for fewer epochs and with less data because they were overfitting to the Train set for more epochs and data. Additional details about the datasets and FL training hyperparameters can be found in Appendix -E.

VI-C2 FL model performance

We measure the perplexity of the final model on the Test set to assess the impact of various duplication levels on model performance. Table I shows the results of perplexity (PP) and improvement rate (IR). IR refers to the percentage of improvement in perplexity after deduplication. For example, the Haiku dataset with GPT-2 Medium and 30% duplication shows an IR of 5.36% from 3.73 to 3.53 after deduplication. The deduplicated client datasets represent the baseline perplexity.

The blue text in the table highlights the largest improvement in perplexity, which is for the Plays dataset with GPT-2 Medium. We observe an improvement rate of 19.61%percent19.6119.61\% from 34.88 to 28.04 for 30%percent3030\% duplication. The Plays dataset in general has a higher perplexity than other datasets as it is a relatively challenging task with longer sequences and fewer training samples. The impact of duplicates in such scenarios is aggravated. We observe a similar trend with the Sonnets dataset with a 13.64%percent13.6413.64\% improvement rate, which is also a difficult task with few samples and relatively long sequences.

The purple text highlights the least improvement in perplexity for the Rotten Tomatoes dataset with GPT-2 Medium. The 10%percent1010\% duplication results in a 1.7%percent1.71.7\% improvement rate from 3.63.63.6 to 3.533.533.53. Similarly, the Haiku and Short Jokes datasets exhibit smaller improvement rates across different levels of duplication, while maintaining low perplexity. We observe these trends because these datasets are relatively easier to learn with a greater number of training samples. The impact of duplicates in such cases is not as pronounced.

The red text highlights two scenarios where deduplication results in insignificant changes (<1%)<1\%) to perplexity. The Plays dataset with GPT-2 Medium shows an improvement of 0.28%percent0.280.28\% after deduplication with 10%percent1010\% duplication while the Sonnets dataset with GPT-2 Large worsens by 0.24%percent0.240.24\% after deduplication with 10%percent1010\% duplication. The reason for the ``noisy'' results for the Plays and Sonnets dataset is that both datasets have very few training data samples. A 10%percent1010\% duplication percentage merely adds 3−5353-5 duplicated data points to each client. Both datasets, however, show significant improvements for 20%percent2020\% and 30%percent3030\% duplication.

VI-C3 FL model training efficiency

We analyze the model training efficiency by computing the total GPU running time of all clients during training. The CPU-bound EP-MPD costs are negligible for 10 clients and at most 5,000 elements (the size of the largest dataset is 50,000 elements distributed among all clients). Table II highlights the results for GPU running time. The Time column is the total GPU running time and IR is the percentage improvement compared to the running time within the deduplicated setting.

The blue text shows the largest improvement in running time of 27.95%percent27.9527.95\% from 33.13 minutes to 23.87 minutes in the GPT-2 Medium experiment with the Sonnets dataset. The purple text highlights the smallest improvement in running time of 7.33%percent7.337.33\% from 11.87 to 11.0 minutes in the Sonnets experiment with GPT-2 Large.

We observe a relatively consistent improvement trend of approximately 22%percent2222\%, 16%percent1616\%, and 8%percent88\% for 30%percent3030\%, 20%percent2020\%, and 10%percent1010\% duplication levels respectively. The GPT-2 Medium experiments show higher running times as these models were trained longer. We observe that the running time efficiency consistently improves across all duplication levels and experiments.

Tables I and II demonstrate the effectiveness of applying EP-MPD to FL of language models. The experiments show improvements of up to 18%percent1818\% in perplexity and 27%percent2727\% in GPU running time. Deduplication significantly reduces resource usage while enhancing the quality of FL models. The RTX A6000 GPU used in our experiments consumes 0.3 kWh of energy. As FL scales to larger datasets and more clients, the energy savings with EP-MPD become even more significant, contributing to more sustainable and cost-effective FL implementations, benefiting both the environment and the end-users.

VII Asymptotic Costs Analysis

In this section, we analyze the asymptotic costs of our schemes. Table III summarizes the result.

VII-A Costs of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}

VII-A1 Computation Cost

Initially, we focus on the computation cost of parties in EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}. In step 1b, each client 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} encrypts each element of its set using the symmetric key encryption 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP}, under each key it agrees with the clients in the other group. Specifically, it invokes 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP} m⋅|Sj,i|⋅𝑚subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖m\cdot|{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}| times, where m𝑚m is the total number of clients in the other group. In step 3, each client 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} invokes 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP} m⋅|Rj,i|⋅𝑚subscript𝑅𝑗𝑖m\cdot|R_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}| times, where Rj,isubscript𝑅𝑗𝑖R_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} is the (encrypted) intersection set. Thus, the computation complexity of each 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} is O​(m⋅|Sj,i|)𝑂⋅𝑚subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖O(m\cdot|{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}|). The computation complexity of 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} in step 2 is O​(m⋅|S|)𝑂⋅𝑚𝑆O(m\cdot|{S}|), where |S|𝑆|{S}| represents the maximum cardinality of sets. The only computation that 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} performs is searching to find duplicated values.

We proceed to analyze the computation cost of parties in EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. In step 2, each client 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} invokes |Sj,i|subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖|{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}| times OPRF to encrypt its set elements. In steps 3 and 4, each 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} performs a search on m+1𝑚1m+1 encrypted sets, which imposes negligible costs compared to the executions of OPRF. Thus, the complexity of each 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} is O​(m⋅|S|)𝑂⋅𝑚𝑆O(m\cdot|{S}|), where |S|𝑆|{S}| is the maximum cardinality of sets. 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} invokes an instance of OPRF in step 2 for every set of elements of each client. Therefore, its computation complexity is O​(m⋅|S|)𝑂⋅𝑚𝑆O(m\cdot|S|), where |S|𝑆|S| is the maximum cardinality of sets.

VII-A2 Communication Cost

We first concentrate on the communication cost of parties in EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}. Each client 𝒞0,isubscript𝒞0𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,i} in step 1a transmits m𝑚m keys to the clients of the other group. Thus, its communication complexity in this step is O​(m)𝑂𝑚O(m). However, the clients in 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} do not transmit any message in this step. In step 1b, each client 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} of each group, transmits m⋅|Sj,i|⋅𝑚subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖m\cdot|{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}| messages to 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}, where the size of each message is only about 256256256 bits. Thus, each client's communication complexity is O​(m⋅|Sj,i|)𝑂⋅𝑚subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖O(m\cdot|S_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}|). On the other hand, 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} sends to each client Rj,isubscript𝑅𝑗𝑖R_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} which contains the intersection the client has with the clients in the other group. Thus, the overall communication complexity of 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} is O​(m⋅|R|)𝑂⋅𝑚𝑅O(m\cdot|R|), where |R|𝑅|R| is the maximum cardinality of sets intersection that a client may have with clients of the other group.

We proceed to evaluate the communication complexity of parties in EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. In step 2, each 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} performs OPRF evaluations on Sj,isubscript𝑆𝑗𝑖{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}. This procedure imposes O​(|Sj,i|)𝑂subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖O(|{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}|) communication cost to the client. In step 3, the communication complexity of each 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} is O​(m⋅|Sj,i|)𝑂⋅𝑚subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖O(m\cdot|{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}|) because it sends its encrypted set to every client in the other group. In step 2, 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} performs OPRF evaluations on the elements of each 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} using OPRF. This procedure imposes O​(m⋅|S|)𝑂⋅𝑚𝑆O(m\cdot|{S}|) communication cost to 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}.

VII-B Costs of EP-MPD

VII-B1 Computation Cost

In step 3, at each level d𝑑d, each client 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} invokes an instance of EG-PSI. When EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} or EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is used, then the computation complexity of 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} in this step is O​(m⋅log2⁡(m)⋅|S|)𝑂⋅𝑚subscript2𝑚𝑆O(m\cdot\log_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(m)\cdot|{S}|), where |S|𝑆|{S}| is the maximum cardinality of the clients' sets. In step 4, 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} updates its set. This involves simply removing items from its local set and the associated cost is negligible compared to other costs. Thus, the overall computation complexity of 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} is O​(m⋅log2⁡(m)⋅|S|)𝑂⋅𝑚subscript2𝑚𝑆O(m\cdot\log_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(m)\cdot|S|). The computation cost is dominated by the cost of executing 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP} and OPRF if EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} are used respectively. The computation complexity of 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} in either case (when EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} or EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is used) is O​(m⋅log2⁡(m)⋅|S|)𝑂⋅𝑚subscript2𝑚𝑆O(m\cdot\log_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(m)\cdot|S|).

VII-B2 Communication Cost

In step 3, at each level d𝑑d, each client 𝒞0,isubscript𝒞0𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,i} transmits its updated set to an instance of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} or EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}. Therefore, its overall communication complexity is O​(m⋅(|S0,i|+∑u=2d(|S0,i|−∑u′=1u−1|S∩(u′)|)))𝑂⋅𝑚subscript𝑆0𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑢2𝑑subscript𝑆0𝑖superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑢′1𝑢1superscriptsubscript𝑆superscript𝑢′O\Big{(}m\cdot\big{(}|{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,i}|+\sum\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle u=2}^{\scriptscriptstyle d}(|{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,i}|-\sum\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle u^{\prime}=1}^{\scriptscriptstyle u-1}|{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle\cap}^{\scriptscriptstyle(u^{\prime})}|)\big{)}\Big{)} where d=log2⁡(m)𝑑subscript2𝑚d=\log_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(m) and |S∩(u′)|superscriptsubscript𝑆superscript𝑢′|{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle\cap}^{\scriptscriptstyle(u^{\prime})}| is the size of the intersection that 𝒞0,isubscript𝒞0𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,i} has with the clients of the other group at level u′superscript𝑢′u^{\prime}. On the other hand, at each level d𝑑d, the communication complexity of each client 𝒞1,isubscript𝒞1𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} is O​(m⋅log2⁡(m)⋅|S1,i|)𝑂⋅𝑚subscript2𝑚subscript𝑆1𝑖O(m\cdot\log_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(m)\cdot|{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}|). Note that the majority of the clients will eventually become members of group 0. Thus, their set size eventually reduces when they (i) proceed to a higher level in the tree and (ii) have intersections with other clients' sets.

The communication complexity of 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}, when EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} is used, is O​(m⋅log2⁡(m)⋅|R|)𝑂⋅𝑚subscript2𝑚𝑅O(m\cdot\log_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(m)\cdot|R|), where |R|𝑅|R| is the maximum cardinality of sets intersection that a client may have with clients of the other group. The communication complexity of 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}, when EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} is used, is O​(m⋅log2⁡(m)⋅|S|)𝑂⋅𝑚subscript2𝑚𝑆O(m\cdot\log_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(m)\cdot|{S}|).

VIII Related Works

A detailed deduplication method has been proposed in [31] that used existing techniques of finding duplicates such as suffix array [36] and MinHash [10]. However, there were no privacy requirements in this method as the data owner is responsible for local deduplication. As we consider the problem of deduplication in a distributive setting, thus our problem statement is fundamentally different from [31].

In [29], the problem of privacy-preserving deduplication by a centralized service was discussed – there is a server that stores multiple users' files after removing duplicates. Their method involves a second server which helps in setting up keys for each user using an OPRF. Our work is different from [29] in many ways. First, we apply OPRF for encrypting the dataset elements, which allows efficient deduplication. Second, our deduplication requirement is more granular – we want entries of users' datasets to be deduplicated. If the two datasets have the same elements irrespective of their order, then at the end of our deduplication, one of the users will receive an empty dataset and the other will receive their dataset unchanged. On the other hand, since [29] considers a file as a whole (not every set element), so two files M1subscript𝑀1M_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} and M2subscript𝑀2M_{\scriptscriptstyle 2} have the same elements but in a different order will not be removed. Third, our public key-based deduplication protocol is federated as opposed to [29] which is centralized (all data is stored in a centralized server responsible for the deduplication). Fourth, [29] is a two-server setting – one server helps in deduplication and the other stores the deduplicated files. In contrast, in our protocol apart from the users, we only have one third-party.

Another work along the lines of [29] is [33] which proposed Multi-Key Revealing Encryption (MKRE) that lets a server compress the encrypted files of multiple users by removing ciphertexts related to similar plaintexts. Their construction is based on message lock encryption, therefore, it is subject to dictionary attacks [34]. Our scheme is not vulnerable to such attacks and, as a result, provides a stronger security guarantee.

The work of [8] also has pointed out the need for data processing for ML and applied PSI-type tools. However, their problem statement is to find a mismatch in the datasets belonging to two participants, whereas we are considering finding duplicates (matching data) in sets belonging to two or more parties. Additionally, their application domain is narrow as they only considered labeled data. Their end goal is to find entries in two different sets where their features match but their corresponding labels do not match. On the other hand, our protocol supports both labeled and unlabeled data.

IX Conclusions

It was established in [31] that machine learning benefits significantly from deduplication. However, it was not evident how federated learning (FL) could benefit from deduplication without compromising data privacy. Our successful and efficient solution to this problem has paved the way for further applications. Our pioneering protocols, EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}, can be employed in any distributed system to identify and efficiently remove duplicates. Although this paper considers elements as duplicates only if they are exact copies, there are scenarios where elements that are not exact matches but are sufficiently similar should also be treated as duplicates [31]. Our current primitives can easily be extended to address this case. By applying fuzzy hash functions, which map closely related elements to the same digest, the deduplication of near-match elements can be reduced to the problem of deduplication of exact-match elements, allowing the use of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} and EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})} in distributed setups. While our system's application focuses on text-based learning, it can also be extended to other areas, such as image processing and speech recognition, thereby broadening its utility and impact.
