-A Security Proof of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}

In this section, we prove the security of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, i.e., Theorem 1.

Proof.

We consider a set of cases where in each case a party is corrupt.

-A1 Corrupt Client

In this case, for the sake of simplicity, we focus on the view of a client 𝒞1,isubscript𝒞1𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} in 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}. Because the clients of both groups behave the same way, with the main difference being that a client in 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} generates a key and sends it to each client of 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}. Thus, the proof asserting the protocol is secure regarding a corrupt client in 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1} will imply the security of the same protocol concerning a client in 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0}.

In the real execution of the protocol, the view of a client, 𝒞1,isubscript𝒞1𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}, is defined as follows:

{𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝒞1,i𝒜,EG-PSI(I)​(S,∅)}S={S1,i,r1,i,k→,R1,i,v→1,i},subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐subscript𝒞1𝑖𝒜superscriptEG-PSII𝑆𝑆subscript𝑆1𝑖subscript𝑟1𝑖→𝑘subscript𝑅1𝑖subscript→𝑣1𝑖\{\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{A},\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}}(S,\emptyset)\}_{\scriptscriptstyle S}=\{S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i},r_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i},\vec{k},R_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i},\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}\},

where S𝑆S is the set containing all clients' sets, r1,isubscript𝑟1𝑖r_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} is the outcome of internal random coins of 𝒞1,isubscript𝒞1𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}, k→=[ki,1,…,ki,m]→𝑘subscript𝑘𝑖1…subscript𝑘𝑖𝑚\vec{k}=[k_{\scriptscriptstyle i,1},\ldots,k_{\scriptscriptstyle i,m}] is a vector of m𝑚m keys received from the clients of 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0}, R1,isubscript𝑅1𝑖R_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} is the encrypted intersection 𝒞1,isubscript𝒞1𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} received from 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}, and v→j,isubscript→𝑣𝑗𝑖\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} equals [v→j,i,1,…,v→j,i,m]subscript→𝑣𝑗𝑖1…subscript→𝑣𝑗𝑖𝑚[\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i,1},\ldots,\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i,m}], each l𝑙l-th vector in v→j,isubscript→𝑣𝑗𝑖\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} contains the elements that are common between 𝒞1,isubscript𝒞1𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}'s set and the set that belongs to the l𝑙l-th client in the other group.

We proceed to construct a simulator, 𝖲𝗂𝗆𝒞1,isubscript𝖲𝗂𝗆subscript𝒞1𝑖\mathsf{Sim}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}}, in the ideal model. The simulator, receiving the client's input S1,isubscript𝑆1𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} and output v→1,isubscript→𝑣1𝑖\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}, operates as follows.

  1. 1.

    initiates an empty view. It appends to it S1,isubscript𝑆1𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} and uniformly random coins r1,i′subscriptsuperscript𝑟′1𝑖r^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}.

  2. 2.

    constructs an empty vector k→′superscript→𝑘′\vec{k}^{\prime} and then chooses m𝑚m keys for 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP}. It appends the keys to k→′superscript→𝑘′\vec{k}^{\prime} and adds k→′superscript→𝑘′\vec{k}^{\prime} to the view.

  3. 3.

    constructs an empty set R′superscript𝑅′R^{\prime}. It encrypts the elements of every l𝑙l-th vector v→1,i,l∈v→1,isubscript→𝑣1𝑖𝑙subscript→𝑣1𝑖\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i,l}\in\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} using l𝑙l-th key klsubscript𝑘𝑙k_{\scriptscriptstyle l} in k→′superscript→𝑘′\vec{k}^{\prime} and 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP}. It inserts the ciphertexts into R′superscript𝑅′R^{\prime}.

  4. 4.

    appends R′superscript𝑅′R^{\prime} and v→1,isubscript→𝑣1𝑖\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} to the view. It outputs the view.

Now, we are prepared to discuss that the two views are computationally indistinguishable. The input set S1,isubscript𝑆1𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} has identical distribution in both models, as their elements are identical. Furthermore, since we are in the semi-honest model, in the real execution of the protocol, the client picks its random coins r1,isubscript𝑟1𝑖r_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} according to the protocol description. In the ideal model, coins r1,i′subscriptsuperscript𝑟′1𝑖r^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} have been selected uniformly at random. Therefore r1,isubscript𝑟1𝑖r_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} and r1,i′subscriptsuperscript𝑟′1𝑖r^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} have identical distributions. Vectors k→→𝑘\vec{k} and k→′superscript→𝑘′\vec{k}^{\prime} have identical distributions too because their elements have been chosen uniformly at random.

In the real model, R1,isubscript𝑅1𝑖R_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} contains the encrypted elements of v→1,isubscript→𝑣1𝑖\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i}, where the keys in k→→𝑘\vec{k} are used for the encryption by applying the 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP}. Similarly, in the ideal model, each element of R′superscript𝑅′R^{\prime} is the encryption of an element in v→1,isubscript→𝑣1𝑖\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} where a key in k→′superscript→𝑘′\vec{k}^{\prime} is used for the encryption with the same 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP}. Thus, R𝑅R and R′superscript𝑅′R^{\prime} have identical distributions. Furthermore, elements of v→1,isubscript→𝑣1𝑖\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,i} are identical in both models; therefore, they have identical distributions in the real and ideal models.

We conclude that the views in the real and ideal models are indistinguishable.

-A2 Corrupt 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}

In the real model, the view of 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} is as follows:

{𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝒯​𝒫𝒜,Γ​(S,∅)}S={(S0,1′,…,S0,m′),(S1,1′,…,S1,m′)}subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝒯𝒫𝒜Γ𝑆𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝑆′01…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′0𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑆′11…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′1𝑚\{\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{TP}}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{A},\Gamma}(S,\emptyset)\}_{\scriptscriptstyle S}=\{({S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m}),({S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m})\}

where each Sj,i′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑗𝑖{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} contains the encrypted set elements of client 𝒞j,isubscript𝒞𝑗𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}. Next, we construct a simulator 𝖲𝗂𝗆𝒯​ℰ​ℰℒsubscriptsuperscript𝖲𝗂𝗆ℒ𝒯ℰℰ\mathsf{Sim}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{L}}_{\mathcal{TEE}} that receives the output s→→𝑠\vec{s} of leakage function ℒℒ\mathcal{L} (as defined in Definition 4).

  1. 1.

    initiates an empty view.

  2. 2.

    constructs m𝑚m empty sets for each 𝒢0subscript𝒢0\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0} and 𝒢1subscript𝒢1\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}. Specifically, it constructs empty sets (S0,1′′,…,S0,m′′⏟𝒢0),(S1,1′′,…,S1,m′′⏟𝒢1)subscript⏟subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′01…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′0𝑚subscript𝒢0subscript⏟subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′11…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′1𝑚subscript𝒢1(\underbrace{{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0}}),(\underbrace{{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{G}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1}}).

  3. 3.

    fills each set Sj,i′′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′𝑗𝑖{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} as follows, given that s→=[s→0,1,…,s→0,m,s→1,1,\vec{s}=[\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m},\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1}, …,s→1,m]\ldots,\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m}], where s→j,i=[|[Sj,i∩S1−j,1]|,…,|[Sj,i∩S1−j,m]|]subscript→𝑠𝑗𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖subscript𝑆1𝑗1…delimited-[]subscript𝑆𝑗𝑖subscript𝑆1𝑗𝑚\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}=\Big{[}\big{|}[{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}\cap{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1-j,1}]\big{|},\ldots,\big{|}[{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}\cap{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1-j,m}]\big{|}\Big{]}, as defined in Definition 3.

    1. (a)

      for every y𝑦y-th element of each s→0,isubscript→𝑠0𝑖\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,i} (where 1≤i,y≤mformulae-sequence1𝑖𝑦𝑚1\leq i,y\leq m) picks s→0,i​[y]subscript→𝑠0𝑖delimited-[]𝑦\vec{s}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,i}[y] random values (from the range of 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP}). It appends these random values to both sets S0,i′′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′0𝑖{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,i} and S1,y′′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′1𝑦{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,y}.

    2. (b)

      pads every set Sj,i′′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′𝑗𝑖{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} with some random values (from the range of 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP}) such that the size of each Sj,i′′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′𝑗𝑖{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} after padding equals the size of Sj,i′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑗𝑖{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i}.

  4. 4.

    appends sets (S0,1′′,…,S0,m′′),(S1,1′′,…,S1,m′′)subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′01…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′0𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′11…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′1𝑚({{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m}}),({{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m}}) to the view and outputs the view.

We proceed to demonstrate that the views in the real and ideal models are computationally indistinguishable. In the real model, each elements of a set Sj,i′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑗𝑖S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} is an output of 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP}. However, in the ideal model, each element of a set Sj,i′′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′𝑗𝑖S^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} has been picked uniformly at random (from the range of 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP}). By the security of 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP} (i.e., an output of 𝙿𝚁𝙿𝙿𝚁𝙿\mathtt{PRP} is computationally indistinguishable from a random value), sets' elements in the real and ideal model are computationally indistinguishable.

Moreover, the size of the intersection between each set S0,i′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′0𝑖S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,i} and each set S1,l′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′1𝑙S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,l} (in the real model) equals the size of the intersection between each set S0,i′′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′0𝑖S^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,i} and each set S1,l′′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′1𝑙S^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,l} (in the ideal model). Furthermore, the size of each Sj,i′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑗𝑖S^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} in the real model equals the size of the corresponding set Sj,i′′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′𝑗𝑖S^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle j,i} in the ideal model. Hence, sets S0,1′,…,S0,m′,S1,1′,…,S1,m′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′01…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′0𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑆′11…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′1𝑚{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m},{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m} in the real model are computationally indistinguishable from sets S0,1′′,…,S0,m′′,S1,1′′,…,S1,m′′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′01…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′0𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′11…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′′1𝑚{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 0,m},{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,1},\ldots,{S}^{\prime\prime}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1,m} in the ideal model.

Thus, the views in the real and ideal models are computationally indistinguishable. ∎

-B Security Proof of EG-PSI(II)superscriptEG-PSIII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{II})}

Proof (sketch).

It is not hard to simulate parties' views. 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}'s view in the real model can be easily simulated given that the main information it learns within the protocol execution includes its view during the invocation of the OPRF instances (but not the outputs of OPRF). If OPRF is secure, then the views of 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE} within the real and ideal model will be computationally indistinguishable in this protocol.

Each client's view (in the real execution of the protocol) mainly includes the outputs of OPRF received from its counterparts and the exchanged messages during OPRF's execution with 𝒯​ℰ​ℰ𝒯ℰℰ\mathcal{TEE}. Due to the security of OPRF, an output of OPRF is computationally indistinguishable from a value picked uniformly at random from the output range of OPRF. Also, the messages each client receives during the execution of OPRF can be simulated, due to the security of OPRF. ∎

-C Security Proof of EP-MPD

In this section, we prove the security of EP-MPD, i.e., Theorem 3. For the sake of concreteness and because we have provided a detailed proof for EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, we will prove Theorem 3 when EP-MPD relies on EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}. The proof for EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}-based EP-MPD will easily follow.

Proof.

In the real execution of the protocol, the view of a client, 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}, is defined as follows:

{𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝒞i𝒜,EP-MPD​(S)}S={Si,𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐→𝒞i,v→i}subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐subscript𝒞𝑖𝒜EP-MPD𝑆𝑆subscript𝑆𝑖subscript→𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐subscript𝒞𝑖subscript→𝑣𝑖\{\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{A},\text{EP-MPD}}(S)\}_{\scriptscriptstyle S}=\{S_{\scriptscriptstyle i},\vec{\mathsf{View}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}},\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}\}

where S={S1,…,Sm}𝑆subscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑚S=\{{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle 1},\ldots,{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle m}\}, Sisubscript𝑆𝑖{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} represents a set belonging to client 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}, 𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐→𝒞i=[𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝒞i,1𝒜,EG-PSI(I),…,𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝒞i,z𝒜,EG-PSI(I)]subscript→𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐subscript𝒞𝑖superscriptsubscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐subscript𝒞𝑖1𝒜superscriptEG-PSII…superscriptsubscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐subscript𝒞𝑖𝑧𝒜superscriptEG-PSII\vec{\mathsf{View}}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}}=[\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i},1}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{A},\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}},\ldots,\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i},z}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{A},\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}}] contains z=l​o​g2​(m)𝑧𝑙𝑜subscript𝑔2𝑚z=log_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}(m) views of 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} such that each view 𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝒞i,d𝒜,EG-PSI(I)superscriptsubscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐subscript𝒞𝑖𝑑𝒜superscriptEG-PSII\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i},d}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{A},\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}} corresponds to 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}'s view when it invokes EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} at level d𝑑d, where 1≤d≤z1𝑑𝑧1\leq d\leq z. Moreover, v→isubscript→𝑣𝑖\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} contains z𝑧z vectors, where each vector v→i,dsubscript→𝑣𝑖𝑑\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle i,d} in v→isubscript→𝑣𝑖\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} is the output of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} that client 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} receives at level d𝑑d.

We proceed to construct a simulator, 𝖲𝗂𝗆𝒞isubscript𝖲𝗂𝗆subscript𝒞𝑖\mathsf{Sim}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}}, in the ideal model. The simulator, receives the output Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{\scriptscriptstyle i} of leakage function 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} (as defined in Definition 6), the client's input Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle i} and output vi→→subscript𝑣𝑖\vec{v_{\scriptscriptstyle i}}. 𝖲𝗂𝗆𝒞isubscript𝖲𝗂𝗆subscript𝒞𝑖\mathsf{Sim}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}} operates as follows.

  1. 1.

    initiates an empty view.

  2. 2.

    for each level d𝑑d (where 1≤d≤z1𝑑𝑧1\leq d\leq z) constructs the following set for each client 𝒞lsubscript𝒞𝑙\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle l} in the other group, using (i) the result v→i,dsubscript→𝑣𝑖𝑑\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle i,d} that 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i} receives at level d𝑑d and (ii) the leakage function's output Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{\scriptscriptstyle i} (hence in total, in level d𝑑d, the simulator will generate 2d2superscript2𝑑2\frac{2^{\scriptscriptstyle d}}{2} sets on behalf of the clients in the other group).

    1. (a)

      constructs an empty set Slsubscript𝑆𝑙S_{\scriptscriptstyle l}.

    2. (b)

      finds every triple (x,a,b)𝑥𝑎𝑏(x,a,b) in Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{\scriptscriptstyle i}, such that a=i𝑎𝑖a=i and b=l𝑏𝑙b=l. It adds the first element x𝑥x of each triple that meets the above conditions to Slsubscript𝑆𝑙S_{\scriptscriptstyle l}. This ensures that Slsubscript𝑆𝑙S_{\scriptscriptstyle l} contains all the elements in common with Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle i}.

    3. (c)

      pads every set Slsubscript𝑆𝑙{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle l} with some random values (from the set universe) such that the size of each Slsubscript𝑆𝑙{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle l}, in the ideal model, after padding equals the size of Slsubscript𝑆𝑙{S}_{\scriptscriptstyle l} in the real model.

  3. 3.

    generates 2d2−1superscript2𝑑21\frac{2^{\scriptscriptstyle d}}{2}-1 empty sets for the group to which Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle i} belongs. It appends to these empty sets values picked uniformly at random from the set universe. It ensures the size of each of these sets in the ideal model equals to that of in the real model.

  4. 4.

    for every level d𝑑d:

    1. (a)

      invokes an instance of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})} using the following sets: (i) Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle i} and sets generated in step 3, that are placed in one group and (ii) sets generated in step 2, placed in another group. As a result, it receives output v→i,dsubscript→𝑣𝑖𝑑\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle i,d}.

    2. (b)

      extracts 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i}'s view 𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝒞i,d𝒜,EG-PSI(I)superscriptsubscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐subscript𝒞𝑖𝑑𝒜superscriptEG-PSII\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i},d}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{A},\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}} after the execution of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}.

    3. (c)

      appends every 𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝒞i,d𝒜,EG-PSI(I)superscriptsubscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐subscript𝒞𝑖𝑑𝒜superscriptEG-PSII\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i},d}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{A},\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}} and v→i,dsubscript→𝑣𝑖𝑑\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle i,d} to its view.

    4. (d)

      outputs the view.

Now, we are prepared to show that the two views (in the real and ideal models) are computationally indistinguishable. The input Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{\scriptscriptstyle i} in both models are identical, therefore they will have identical distribution.

Due to the security of EG-PSI(I)superscriptEG-PSII\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}, for every level d𝑑d, 𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐𝒞i,d𝒜,EG-PSI(I)superscriptsubscript𝖵𝗂𝖾𝗐subscript𝒞𝑖𝑑𝒜superscriptEG-PSII\mathsf{View}_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{C}_{\scriptscriptstyle i},d}^{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{A},\text{EG-PSI}^{\scriptscriptstyle(\text{I})}} in the real and ideal models are computationally indistinguishable, as demonstrated in the proof of Theorem 1. Furthermore, the intersection v→i,dsubscript→𝑣𝑖𝑑\vec{v}_{\scriptscriptstyle i,d} that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} learns at every level d𝑑d in the real and ideal model are identical, thus they are indistinguishable.

Hence, the views of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in the real and ideal models are computationally indistinguishable. ∎

-D Related Work in PSI Research

Since their introduction in [19], numerous PSIs have been designed. In general, PSIs fall into two broad categories traditional and delegated. In traditional PSIs, clients (i.e., data owners) compute the result interactively using their data stored locally. In this research line, researchers in [45] introduced two two-party PSIs, one secure against semi-honest and the other against malicious (or active) adversaries. These protocols are the fastest two-party PSIs to date. They use Oblivious Key-Value Stores (OKVS) data structure and Vector Oblivious Linear Evaluation (VOLE). These solutions' computation cost is O​(c)𝑂𝑐O(c), where c𝑐c is a set's cardinality. They also impose O​(c​log⁡c2+κ)𝑂𝑐superscript𝑐2𝜅O(c\log c^{\scriptscriptstyle 2}+\kappa) and O​(c⋅κ)𝑂⋅𝑐𝜅O(c\cdot\kappa) communication costs in the semi-honest and malicious models respectively, where κ𝜅\kappa is a security parameter.

Dorre et al. [17] proposed an efficient two-party PSI that requires each party to locally posses a secure hardware, a requirement that may not always be possible to meet. The scheme further relies on a hash function and deterministic symmetric-key encryption. The scheme's communication complexity is O​(p​o​l​y​(κ)+|S|​λ)𝑂𝑝𝑜𝑙𝑦𝜅𝑆𝜆O(poly(\kappa)+|S|\lambda) and its computation complexity is O​((2⋅|S|)⋅p​o​l​y​(κ⋅l))𝑂⋅⋅2𝑆𝑝𝑜𝑙𝑦⋅𝜅𝑙O((2\cdot|S|)\cdot poly(\kappa\cdot l)), where l𝑙l is a set element's bit size and λ𝜆\lambda is a security parameter. As the authors stated, the protocol cannot directly support multiple more than two parties.

Furthermore, researchers developed PSIs that allows multiple (i.e., more than two) parties to compute the intersection. The multi-party PSIs in [24, 30] are secure against semi-honest adversaries while those proposed in [6, 20, 53, 30, 40] were developed to remain secure against active ones. The protocols in [30] and [40] are the most efficient multi-party PSIs designed to be secure against passive and active adversaries respectively. The computation and communication complexities of the PSI in [30] are O​(c⋅m2+c⋅m)𝑂⋅𝑐superscript𝑚2⋅𝑐𝑚O(c\cdot m^{\scriptscriptstyle 2}+c\cdot m) and O​(c⋅m2)𝑂⋅𝑐superscript𝑚2O(c\cdot m^{\scriptscriptstyle 2}). The PSI in [40] has a parameter t𝑡t that determines how many parties can collude with each other and must be set before the protocol's execution, where t∈[2,m)𝑡2𝑚t\in[2,m). Its computation and communication complexities are O​(c⋅κ​(m+t2−t​(m+1)))𝑂⋅𝑐𝜅𝑚superscript𝑡2𝑡𝑚1O(c\cdot\kappa(m+t^{\scriptscriptstyle 2}-t(m+1))) and O​(c⋅m⋅κ)𝑂⋅𝑐𝑚𝜅O(c\cdot m\cdot\kappa) respectively.

Delegated PSIs use cloud computing for computation and/or storage. These PSIs can be further categorized into those that allow one-off and repeated delegation of PSI computation. The most efficient one that supports one-off delegation is [26], designed for the two-party setting, with an overhead of O​(c)𝑂𝑐O(c). Researchers also proposed a multi-party PSI that supports repeated delegation and efficient updates [16]. It imposes O​(h⋅d2⋅m)𝑂⋅ℎsuperscript𝑑2𝑚O(h\cdot d^{\scriptscriptstyle 2}\cdot m) and O​(h⋅d⋅m)𝑂⋅ℎ𝑑𝑚O(h\cdot d\cdot m) computation and communication costs respectively, during the PSI computation. Furthermore, to incentivize clients to participate in a PSI protocol and share their sensitive inputs, researchers proposed a PSI that rewards participants [1].

Thus, despite the development of numerous two-party and multiple-party PSIs, none of them to date can match the features offered by our PSIs.

-E Datasets and FL Hyperparameters

We use the following datasets in our study:

  1. 1.

    Haiku222https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/bfbarry/haiku-dataset: This dataset contains 15,281 Haikus scraped from ``reddit.com/r/haiku''. Haiku is a Japanese style of short poetry.

  2. 2.

    Rotten Tomatoes333https://huggingface.co/datasets/cornell-movie-review-data/rotten_tomatoes: It contains 10,662 movie reviews from the Rotten Tomatoes movie critic website. Originally intended for sentiment analysis, the dataset has 5,331 positive and negative reviews each. In our experiments, we ignore the sentiment of the reviews and train the CLM only on the review.

  3. 3.

    Short Jokes444https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/abhinavmoudgil95/short-jokes: It contains 231,657 jokes scraped from Reddit. We randomly sample 50,000 jokes for our experiments.

  4. 4.

    Poetry555https://huggingface.co/datasets/merve/poetry: It contains 573 poems from the Renaissance and Modern eras by various poets.

  5. 5.

    IMDB [35]: This dataset contains 50,000 movie reviews from the IMDB movie critic website. Similar to the Rotten Tomatoes dataset, the IMDB dataset was originally intended for sentiment analysis. We ignore the sentiment of each review and only train the CLM on the review.

  6. 6.

    Sonnets666https://huggingface.co/datasets/Lambent/shakespeare_sonnets_diffused: This dataset contains 460 sonnets (including variations) from William Shakespeare. Sonnets are 14-line poems with variable rhyme schemes

  7. 7.

    Plays777https://huggingface.co/datasets/Trelis/tiny-shakespeare: It contains 521 plays from William Shakespeare.

We train the GPT-2 Medium and GPT-2 Large models for 5​–​105–105\text{--}10 and 1​–​21–21\text{--}2 local epochs respectively. Both models are trained for 5 rounds. The Haiku GPT-2 Large was trained for 1 epoch while the other GPT-2 Large models were trained for 2 epochs. The Poetry and Sonnets GPT-2 Medium models were trained for 10 epochs while the others were trained for 5 epochs. We observe that training GPT-2 Large for more epochs and data results in overfitting and poor Test set perplexity across all duplication levels.

For all experiments, we use a learning of 5×10−55superscript1055\times 10^{\scriptscriptstyle-5} with the AdamW [32] optimizer. We use a linear warm-up schedule with 10% of the training steps as warm-up steps. We use ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{\scriptscriptstyle 2}-norm clipping for the gradients and set the threshold to 1.0. We set the sequence length for the datasets as follows:

  1. 1.

    Haiku: 100

  2. 2.

    Rotten Tomatoes: 200

  3. 3.

    Short Jokes: 100

  4. 4.

    Poetry: 1000

  5. 5.

    IMDB: 500

  6. 6.

    Sonnets: 400

  7. 7.

    Plays: 1000

For the Short Jokes dataset, we randomly sample 50,000 elements to ensure the running time is feasible as we train with 10 clients. We set the batch size to values in the range [4,32]432[4,32], depending on the sequence length and model size to ensure that training can be performed on one RTX A6000 GPU. We use a Train/Test split of 80/20 for all datasets. In the case of datasets like IMDB that have a separate Test set, we combine the original Train and Test sets into a single dataset, shuffle it, and then create 80:20 splits. We fix the random seed to 123 for the Numpy, PyTorch, and Python random number generators to ensure the reproducibility of our results.
